{{RomanMilitary}}
The '''''Limes Arabicus''''' was a desert frontier of the [[Roman Empire]], mostly in the province of [[Arabia Petraea]].{{dubious|Ar. P. = Jordan+Negev+N. Sinai, and it isn't anywhere close to 1500 km long on its E border. Syria wasn't part of it.|date= April 2018}} It ran northeast from the [[Gulf of Aqaba]] for about {{convert|1,500 |km|sp=us|sigfig=2}} at its greatest extent, reaching northern [[Syria]] and forming part of the wider Roman ''[[limes]]'' system. It had several forts and watchtowers.
The reason of this defensive ''limes'' was to protect the Roman province of Arabia from attacks of the barbarian tribes of the [[Arabian Peninsula|Arabian]] desert.<ref>{{Cite journal| issn = 0003-097X| issue = 247| pages = 1–26| last = Parker| first = S. Thomas| title = Preliminary Report on the 1980 Season of the Central "Limes Arabicus" Project| journal = Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research| date = 1982-07-01| jstor = 1356476 }}</ref> The main purpose of the ''Limes Arabicus'' is disputed; it may have been used both to defend from [[Arab]] raids and to protect the commercial lines from robbers.
Next to the Limes Arabicus Emperor [[Trajan]] built a major road, the [[Via Nova Traiana]], from [[Bosra]] to [[Aqaba|Aila]] on the [[Red Sea]], a distance of {{cvt|430|km}}. Built between 111 and 114 AD, its primary purpose may have been to provide efficient transportation for troop movements and government officials as well as facilitating and protecting trade caravans emerging from the Arabian Peninsula. It was completed under Emperor [[Hadrian]].<ref>Young, Gary K. ''Rome's Eastern Trade: International commerce and imperial policy, 31 BC – AD 305'' p. 119</ref>
==Fortification== During the [[Severan dynasty]] (AD 193–235), the Romans strengthened their defences on the Arabian frontier. They constructed several [[castra]] (forts) at the northwest end of the [[Wadi Sirhan]], and improved the roads. One important fort was [[Qasr Azraq]], another was at [[Humeima]] (Latin: Auara), from the late [[2nd century|2nd C AD]], on the Via Nova from Petra to [[Ayla (city)|Aila]], where up to 500 auxiliary troops could have resided. It was probably abandoned in the fourth century.<ref>[http://www.vkrp.org/studies/historical/roman-forts/info/castella.asp Roman castra of Humeima] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121209135358/http://www.vkrp.org/studies/historical/roman-forts/info/castella.asp |date=2012-12-09 }}</ref>
[[file:Dioecesis_Orientis_400_AD.png|thumb|right|Diocese of the East around 400 AD]] Emperor [[Diocletian]] partitioned the old province of [[Arabia Felix|Arabia]] by transferring the southern region to the province of Palaestina. Later in the [[4th century]], Palaestina was made into three provinces, and the southern one was eventually called ''[[Palaestina Salutaris|Palaestina Tertia]]''. Each province was administered by a [[praeses]] with civil authority and a [[dux]] with military authority.
[[Diocletian]] engaged in a major military expansion in the region, building a number of [[castellum|castella]], watchtowers, and fortresses along the fringe of the desert just east of the Via Nova. This line of defence extended from south of [[Damascus]] to [[Wadi Zered|Wadi al-Hasa]]. The region from [[Wadi Mujib]] to [[Wadi al-Hasa]] contained four [[castra|castella]] and a [[Roman legion|legion]]ary camp. The frontier south of Wadi al-Hasa, which extended to the [[Red Sea]] at Aila (Aqaba), may have been called the ''Limes Palaestina''.<ref>Parker 1986, p. 6</ref> In this region, ten castella and a legionary camp have been identified. The term may have referred to a series of fortifications and roads in the northern [[Negev]], running from [[Rafah]] on the [[Mediterranean]] to the [[Dead Sea]],<ref>Gichon 1991</ref> or to the region under the military control of the ''dux Palaestinae'', the military governor of the Palaestinian provinces.<ref>Isaac 1990, pp. 408 – 409</ref>
==Personnel== There were [[castra]] every {{convert|100|km}} with the purpose to create a line of protection and control:<ref>[http://www.vkrp.org/studies/historical/roman-forts/info/limes-arabicus-purpose.asp Purpose of Roman castra in Arabia] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130416060402/http://www.vkrp.org/studies/historical/roman-forts/info/limes-arabicus-purpose.asp |date=2013-04-16 }}</ref> in the south there was the legionary fortress at Adrou ([[Udruh, El Quweira|Udruh]]), just east of [[Petra]]. It probably housed the [[Legio VI Ferrata]], which was moved from [[Lajjun]] (in modern-day Israel) by Diocletian.<ref>{{Cite book|publisher=John Wiley & Sons |isbn=9781405181440 |last=Erdkamp |first=Paul |title=A Companion to the Roman Army |date=2008 |page=253}}</ref> It is similar to [[Betthorus]] ([[el-Lejjun (Jordan)|al-Lajjun]] in modern-day Jordan) in size ({{convert|12|acre|disp=flip}}) and design, and is in the plain of Moab, south of Wadi Mujib . Alistair Killick, who excavated the site, dates it to the early 2nd century, but Parker suggests a date in the late 3rd or early 4th century.
A legionary camp may have also existed at Aila (modern [[Aqaba]]), which has been excavated by Parker since 1994. The city was located at the north end of the Gulf of Aqaba where it was a centre of sea traffic. Several land routes also intersected here. [[Legio X Fretensis]], originally stationed in [[Jerusalem]], was transferred here to the terminus of the Via Nova. So far, a stone [[Curtain wall (fortification)|curtain wall]] and projecting tower have been identified, but it is uncertain whether they were part of the city wall of Aila or the fortress. The evidence suggests the fort was constructed in the late 4th or early 5th century.
Troops were progressively withdrawn from the ''Limes Arabicus'' in the first half of the 6th century and replaced with native Arab ''[[foederati]]'', chiefly the [[Ghassanids]].<ref>[http://www.vkrp.org/studies/historical/roman-forts/info/frontier-end.asp End of Limes Arabicus] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120919012842/http://www.vkrp.org/studies/historical/roman-forts/info/frontier-end.asp |date=2012-09-19 }}</ref> After the [[Muslim conquest of the Levant|Muslim Arab conquest]], the ''Limes Arabicus'' was largely left to disappear, though some fortifications were used and reinforced in the following centuries.

'''''LoliRock''''' is a French animated television series produced by [[Marathon Media]] and [[Zodiak Kids]]. It was created by Jean Louis-Vandestoc and written by Madellaine Paxson.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://kidscreen.com/2013/03/25/marathon-to-bring-music-to-girls-ears-with-lolirock/ |title=Marathon to bring music to girls' ears with Lolirock |last=Getzler |first=Wendy Goldman |date=25 March 2013 |website=Kidscreen}}</ref> It first aired in France on 18 October 2014 on [[France 3]], and has expanded to television channels in Europe.<ref name="licensemag 20131001">{{Cite web |url=http://www.licensemag.com/license-global/lolirock-gets-ready-rock |title=Lolirock Gets Ready to Rock |last=Jenkins |first=Bob |date=1 October 2013 |website=License! Global |publisher=[[UBM plc|UBM]] |access-date=19 June 2016}}</ref> It has also been licensed in United States, Canada, United Kingdom and Australia, with an English dub released to Netflix on 1 May 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://unogs.com/video/?v=80101826|title=Netflix Global Search on uNoGS|website=unogs.com|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>
== Plot == Iris is a teenage girl who likes to sing and help others. However, when she sings, strange events happen. Encouraged by her best friend Nathaniel, Iris auditions for a girl rock band, but her power destroys the room and she is later attacked by two strangers. The judges at the audition, Talia and Auriana, come to help her, and they explain to her that she is actually a princess with magical powers who must save her kingdom of Ephedia from the clutches of Gramorr, who has taken over. The only way to save it is to master her powers and to find the Oracle Gems of the Royal Crown of Ephedia, which are scattered across the Earth. Over the course of the series, the three girls try to live as both ordinary teenagers as well as rock stars of the [[all-girl band]] "LoliRock", while training Iris in secret and gathering the gems. But when Gramorr sends twin siblings Praxina and Mephisto to fight them and summon monsters to cause chaos, the girls must work together as magical girl warrior princesses.
In season 2, the three girls are joined by Ephedian girls Carissa and Lyna, who also transform into warrior princesses, but are not part of the band. <!-- http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/153557107138/lolirock-season-2-production-over-drawing --> The girls continue gathering Oracle Gems while helping those in need, but Gramorr and the evil twins continue to get stronger as well. When the last oracle gem is collected, Iris faces the reality of having to say goodbye to Nathaniel and returning to Ephedia, but when Gramorr claims the final gem and is freed, the girls work together to face him in one last battle.
== Characters == [[File:Tabitha St. Germain.png|thumb|right|[[Tabitha St. Germain]] voiced several of the key characters in ''LoliRock'' including Auriana, Amaru, Aunt Ellen, and Carissa]] <!-- The following are listed with star billing for the voice actors --> * '''{{vanchor|Iris}}''' (voiced by [[Kazumi Evans]] in English version,<ref name="english cast">{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/133994103918/lolirock-season-1-full-english-voice-cast-all |title=LoliRock Season 1 – Full english voice cast |last=Team LoliRock |date=26 November 2015 |access-date=13 June 2016 |work=Tumblr}}</ref><!-- https://web.archive.org/web/20160620190743/http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/133994103918/lolirock-season-1-full-english-voice-cast-all --> Lisa Caruso in French version<ref name="french cast">{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/133994170213/lolirock-season-1-full-french-cast-all-the |title=LoliRock Season 1 – Full french cast |last=Team LoliRock |date=26 November 2015 |access-date=17 June 2016 |work=Tubmlr}}</ref><!-- save to archive https://web.archive.org/web/20160620190842/http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/133994170213/lolirock-season-1-full-french-cast-all-the -->) – The lead singer of LoliRock, Iris is a 15-year-old{{efn|The ages for the other characters are listed at the LoliRock production Tumblr: {{cite web|url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/142466362148/i-always-wonder-how-old-is-izira-mephisto |title=Team LoliRock – I always wonder how old is izira, mephisto,... |date=8 April 2016 |accessdate=15 June 2016 |author=Team LoliRock |work=Tumblr |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424163804/http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/142466362148/i-always-wonder-how-old-is-izira-mephisto |archivedate=24 April 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }}}}<!-- save to archive https://web.archive.org/web/20160620190923/http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/142466362148/i-always-wonder-how-old-is-izira-mephisto --><ref name="issuu catalog"/> girl living in Sunny Bay; she has wavy blonde hair, fair skin, light blue eyes, pink lips and freckles. She is kind-hearted and willing to help everyone. She has a singing power that seems to enchant everything around her; this power is coveted by Gramorr. She has a crush on her childhood best friend, Nathaniel. After she meets Talia and Auriana, she discovers that she is the crown princess of Ephedia, a magical kingdom, and her duty is to find all the Oracle Gems of the Royal Crown and to reclaim the throne of Ephedia. When she transforms using a [[pendant]], her hair turns rose pink and her clothes turn pink, and she has a [[Heart (symbol)|heart symbol]] and a four-pointed star symbol.<ref name="tumblr 20160511"/> The production Tumblr said that she gets two symbols because she is in the royal family which rules the realm and the entire planet.<ref name="tumblr 20160429">{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/143555226768/now-that-we-are-talking-about-magic-circles-i-need |title=Now that we are talking about magic circles I need... |last=Team LoliRock |date=29 April 2016 |access-date=15 June 2016 |work=Tumblr}}</ref><!-- per [[H:LIST]] guidelines on paragraphs
-->{{pb}} Character designer Bertrand Todesco initially considered Iris as having dark hair that would change to blonde in the transformation, but found that to be a cliché, and instead went with pop and girly colours like [[Katy Perry]]. Iris was based on actress [[Taylor Momsen]] from ''[[Gossip Girl]]'', and the wardrobe was based on a picture of [[Blake Lively]], also from ''Gossip Girl'', in a green dress.<ref name="design1">{{Cite web |url=http://bertrandtodesco.tumblr.com/post/128296427777/back-to-2011-the-creation-of-lolirock-part-1 |title=Back to 2011! The creation of LoliRock – Part 1: Iris Genesis |last=Todesco |first=Bertrand |date=4 September 2015 |access-date=13 June 2016 |work=Tumblr}}</ref><!-- https://web.archive.org/web/20151017092026/http://bertrandtodesco.tumblr.com/post/128296427777/back-to-2011-the-creation-of-lolirock-part-1 --> He also cited British singer [[Pixie Lott]] as a reference.<ref name="design3">{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/128547659393/bertrandtodesco-back-to-2011-the-creation-of |title=Back to 2011! The creation of LoliRock – Part 3: Finalizing main characters |last=Todesco |first=Bertrand |date=7 September 2015 |access-date=13 June 2016 |work=Tumblr}}</ref>{{pb}}<!-- per [[H:LIST]] guidelines
---> * '''{{vanchor|Talia}}''' (voiced by [[Ashleigh Ball (voice actress)|Ashleigh Ball]] in English version,<ref name="english cast"/> Kelly Marot in French version<ref name="french cast"/>) – She sings vocals and plays the [[keytar]] and sometimes guitar in LoliRock. She has long dark brown hair with straight bangs, dark skin, and amber eyes. She is serious, kind, and very intelligent. As the second princess of Xeris, she was imprisoned by Gramorr before going on the search for the princess of Ephedia with the help of Auriana. Her transformation item is a [[bracelet]]; her hair turns light blue and her clothes become blue. Her symbol is the [[Lozenge|diamond]].<ref name="tumblr 20160511"/><!-- per [[H:LIST]] guidelines on paragraphs
-->{{pb}} Taila's character reference was French fashion blogger Betty Autier and her wardrobe, [[Amber Stevens West]] as she portrayed Ashleigh Owens in the TV series ''[[Greek (TV series)|Greek]]'', and singers [[Keri Hilson]] and [[Alicia Keys]].<ref name="design3"/>{{pb}}<!-- per [[H:LIST]] guidelines
---> * '''{{vanchor|Auriana}}''' (voiced by [[Tabitha St. Germain]] in English version,<ref name="english cast"/> Léopoldine Serre in French version<ref name="french cast"/>) – She sings vocals and plays [[tambourine]] in LoliRock. She has auburn hair styled in a ponytail, tan skin, and green eyes. She is bubbly, playful, boy-crazy, and a bit air-headed, but a reliable friend. She is the princess of Volta. Her transformation item is a ring; her hair and clothes turn bright orange, and she sports a longer ponytail. Her symbol is a [[Crescent|crescent moon]].<ref name="tumblr 20160511"/><!-- per [[H:LIST]] guidelines on paragraphs
-->{{pb}} Todesco wrote that Auriana's original name was Aurora and that he had pictured her as a black girl with a huge volume of hair, and that Talia would be maybe Asian with long straight hair, but he later changed the hairstyles.<ref name="design2">{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/128391084118/bertrandtodesco-back-to-2011-the-creation-of |title=Back to 2011! The creation of LoliRock – Part 2: Talia and Aurora |last=Todesco |first=Bertrand |date=5 September 2015 |access-date=13 June 2016 |work=Tumblr}}</ref> He wrote that Auriana was "all the other cool things I like and I couldn't put on Iris and/or Talia." Auriana's character reference was [[Leighton Meester]] from ''Gossip Girl'' and [[Cat Valentine (Victorious)|Cat Valentine]] (played by [[Ariana Grande]]) from the teen sitcom ''[[Victorious (TV series)|Victorious]]''. He said that the name choice was a coincidence.<ref name="design3"/>{{pb}}<!-- per [[H:LIST]] guidelines
---> * '''{{vanchor|Amaru}}''' (vocalisations by Tabitha St. Germain<ref name="english cast"/><ref name="french cast"/>) – A purple and white furry creature with dark blue hair and a fluffy little tail. He has the ability to transform into a winged horse and to transport the princesses and their enemies to a special arena to allow the princesses to fight evil away from any civilians.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://tuauraslesyeuxcarres.wordpress.com/2014/10/15/lolirock-magical-girls-a-la-francaise/ |title=LoliRock – Magical Girls à la française |work=Tu auras les yeux carrés }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/143580614453/hello-i-have-two-questions-1-is-black-crystal |title=Hello, I have two questions, 1 is black crystal... |last=Team LoliRock |date=29 April 2016 |access-date=15 June 2016 |work=Tumblr | quote=Now, the Battle Arena. It's a pocket dimension that Amaru is able to summon at will, bringing with him the people nearby. How does he do it ? It's very mysterious. The main purpose for the Arena is to allow the princesses to fight with their full power without worrying of consequences : there are no civilians (usually) nor anything valuable (buildings, vehicules, etc) in the Arena.}}</ref> Todesco created Amaru out of the magical girl concept of having pets such as with Sailor Moon having a cat, and that Amaru would be able to transform into a keyring plush on her bag.<ref name="design1"/>{{pb}}<!-- per [[H:LIST]] guidelines
---> * '''{{vanchor|Gramorr|Banes}}''' (voiced by [[Mackenzie Gray]] in English version,<ref name="english cast"/> Gilles Morvan in French version<ref name="french cast"/>) – The Grand Wizard of Chaos. He has blond hair and purple eyes, wears a crown as well as a mask that covers his nose and mouth. After betraying the king and queen, Gramorr has taken control of Ephedia. However, to gain total control of the kingdom, he must have the royal crown, which is protected by a spell. He is thus unable to leave the castle area and must rely on Praxina and Mephisto to do his work.<ref name="tumblr 20160526"/><ref name="design7"/> He has a [[black panther]] minion named Banes, which is described by the production Tumblr as the anti-Amaru, and was created to give Gramorr more presence.<ref name="design7">{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/132243960370/lolirock-characters-7-gramorr-and-banes-the-grand |title=LoliRock characters 7: Gramorr and Banes |last=Team LoliRock |date=31 October 2015 |access-date=15 June 2016 |work=Tumblr}}</ref> In early promotions for the series, Gramorr was named Gromar and he was depicted as Iris's evil uncle who imprisoned the king and queen, and had sent his two evil twin nephews to Earth to thwart Lolirock and take the gems,<ref name="licensemag 20131001"/> but the idea was scrapped as it would have made him more of a stereotype.<ref name="uncle gramorr rejected"/>{{pb}}<!-- per [[H:LIST]] guidelines
---> * '''{{vanchor|Praxina}}''' (voiced by [[Kelly Sheridan]] in English version,<ref name="english cast"/> Karine Foviau in French version<ref name="french cast"/>) – She has long burgundy-colored hair that typically covers one of her eyes. She loves to belittle people, especially her enemies and her twin brother, the latter of whom she reminds that she was born before. She has a very affirmed personality and often bosses her brother around. Her theme colour is red. Her attacks tend to be demonstrations of raw power with explosions and large summoned monsters.<ref name="tumblr 20160602">{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/145316083198/if-black-magic-harms-both-the-caster-and-the |title=If black magic harms both the caster and the... |last=Team LoliRock |date=2 June 2016 |access-date=15 June 2016 |work=Tumblr | quote=Praxina prefers demonstrations of raw power, like big explosion spells and huge monster summoning. And she's good at that. Mephisto prefers more elaborate spells and tricks (he likes to brag how he's a genius, remember ?), like trying to put all princesses to sleep, or removing Iris' memory, things like that. He however is as capable as her to summon monsters and freeze people in black crystal. And she is also capable of being more subtle when needed. ==Production== ===Conception=== Jean-Louis Vandestoc drew inspiration for ''LoliRock'' from watching anime in his childhood that was broadcast on the French channels, including ''[[Sherlock Hound]]'', ''[[Space Adventure Cobra]]'', ''[[The Mysterious Cities of Gold]]'' and ''[[Dragon Ball]]'', but his most influential title he watched was ''[[Magical Princess Minky Momo]]''. He wrote "I loved the very core of it: a child transforming into an adult, helping people and making good deeds, the nice chara design, and finally the tone of the show: it could be funny and light, but also dramatic and tearful at other times. My soul was marked forever." After working on French cartoons ''[[Monster Buster Club]]'' and ''[[Rekkit Rabbit]]'' he wanted to make a [[magical girl]] show. He chose ''[[Sailor Moon]]'' and ''[[Pretty Cure]]'' as references for the magical girl part, and ''[[Jem and the Holograms]]'' for the music career part. <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/124158192967/back-to-the-roots |title=Back to the roots |last=Jean-Louis Vandestoc / Team LoliRock |date=15 July 2015 |access-date=19 January 2017 |work=Tumblr}}</ref>
===Character design=== {{multiple image <!-- Layout --> | align = <!-- right (default), left, centre, none --> | direction = <!-- horizontal (default), vertical --> | background colour = <!-- box background --> | total_width = 360 <!-- total width of all the displayed images in pixels (an integer, omit "px" suffix) --> | caption_align = <!-- left (default), centre, right -->
<!-- Header --> | header_background = | header_align = <!-- centre (default), left, right --> | header =
<!--image 1--> | image1 = Taylor Momsen 2011.jpg | width1 = 2543<!-- full width of the ORIGINAL UNSCALED image --> | height1 = 2646<!-- full height of the ORIGINAL UNSCALED image --> | alt1 = | caption1 = [[Taylor Momsen]], character reference for Iris
<!--image 2--> | image2 = Amber Stevens_2010.jpg | width2 = 1152 <!-- full width of the ORIGINAL UNSCALED image --> | height2 = 1728 <!-- full height of the ORIGINAL UNSCALED image --> | alt2 = | caption2 = [[Amber Stevens West]], character reference for Talia
<!--image 3--> | image3 = Victorious Cast in Concert cropped.png | width3 = 327 <!-- full width of the ORIGINAL UNSCALED image --> | height3 = 712 <!-- full height of the ORIGINAL UNSCALED image --> | alt3 = | caption3 = [[Ariana Grande]] character reference for Auriana <!-- Footer --> | footer_background = | footer_align = <!-- left (default), centre, right --> | footer = }} The producers at Marathon Media asked designers to draw Iris for a [[magical girl]] project as a teenage alien princess with ice/crystal powers. Character designer Bertrand Todesco drew inspiration from Betty Autier, a French fashion blogger of "le blog de betty". She had dark hair and straight bangs, but Todesco figured the producers wanted a blonde girl for a lead, so he went with the look of [[Jenny Humphrey]] of the TV series ''[[Gossip Girl]]'', portrayed by [[Taylor Momsen]]. The producers also wanted the girls' irises to be star-shaped. Autier's appearance as well as her wardrobe was retained for Talia.<ref name="design1"/>
Following the initial picture, Todesco needed to design a princess/rockstar outfit, of which he chose a green dress worn by [[Blake Lively]]. The colour was changed to pink as green was not suitable for merchandising. Todeco added a magical pet creature in the custom of ''[[Sailor Moon]]'', which would later become Amaru. He designed in the hair streaks for when the girls were rock stars, and dresses that weren't so frilly that they would be complicated to draw.<ref name="design1"/>
In designing Talia and the then-named Aurora, Todesco originally started with a black girl and an Asian girl with typical hairstyles, but later changed his mind.<ref name="design2"/> He then found inspirations from other ''Gossip Girl'' characters as well as actresses [[Amber Stevens West]] and [[Ariana Grande]], the latter of whom was how she acted in the teen sitcom ''[[Victorious (TV series)|Victorious]]'' rather than her current pop singer image. He also referenced [[Keri Hilson]] and [[Alicia Keys]]. ''Victorious'' was also the inspiration for some of the key visuals he used in promoting the series to get funding.<ref name="design3"/>
Early promotions of the series pictured the antagonist named Gromar to be an evil uncle of Iris who imprisoned the king and queen, and that he sent his two evil twin nephews to Earth to thwart Lolirock and take the gems.<ref name="licensemag 20131001"/> Paxson said that they abandoned the idea as it would have made him more of a stereotype.<ref name="uncle gramorr rejected">{{cite web|url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/124071399250/interview-with-writer-madellaine-paxson-behind|title=Interview with Writer Madellaine Paxson – Behind the Scenes – LoliRock|author=Team LoliRock|date=14 July 2015|work=Tumblr|accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref> Todesco originally conceived of antagonists Praxina and Mephisto to have guitar playing sound powers that would counter the girls' singing voice powers but the idea was abandoned.<ref name="design5"/> After several iterations, Praxina's final design was approved where she would have a butterfly brooch and motif, while Mephisto's was approved later, after director Jean-Louis had suggested he have a snake motif and a half-covered face.<ref name="design5"/><ref name="design6"/> Eventually Gramorr would have the covered face,<ref name="design7"/><ref name="design6"/>
The design for the crystal [[magic circle]]s and related animation was first done in 2D based off some reference pictures. Different colours and symbols were assigned to each character. It was later created in CGI.<ref name="tumblr 20160511">{{cite web | url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/144189468088/lolirock-research-development-the-crystal | title=LoliRock Research & Development : The Crystal Magic | date=11 May 2016 | accessdate=15 June 2016 | author=Team LoliRock |work=Tumblr}}</ref> Animation tools used include [[Toon Boom Animation|Toon Boom Harmony]], [[Adobe After Effects]], and [[Blender (software)|Blender]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/147387459038/hello-i-started-watching-lolirock-on-netfilx-with#notes | title=Hello! I started watching Lolirock on Netfilx with our daughter. We really enjoy it:) I was wondering what program is used to animate Lolirock? | quote=LoliRock is animated with Toonboom Harmony. The compositing is done with Adobe After Effect. And the CGI parts (vehicules, crystals, and some props) is created with Blender. | date=14 July 2016 | accessdate=4 October 2016 |work=Tumblr | author=Team LoliRock }}</ref>
Lyna and Carissa were created in response to a request from the producers when the writing for season 1 was nearing completion. The request was to add two new princesses to increase the member count to five. However, the LoliRock developers thought they already had too many characters so they made Lyna and Carissa supporting characters that were "outside the main gang but always ready and willing to help when needed". The two girls' transformations resemble Sailor Uranus and Sailor Neptune. The designers considered making one of the two girls look Asian to balance out the overall group's look; they applied the look to both girls, and chose Lyna. There was also a concern that Carissa might be confused with Auriana as the show's redhead, they decided to go with giving her an Irish redhead theme anyway.<ref name="lyna and carissa dev">{{cite web|url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/162714405036/lyna-carissas-developpment|title=Lyna & Carissa's Developpment|author=Team LoliRock|date=7 July 2017 |work=Tumblr|accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref>
===Themes and writing=== ''LoliRock'' head writer Madellaine Paxson, who had worked on children's shows ''[[Making Fiends (TV series)|Making Fiends]]'', ''[[Power Rangers RPM]]'' as well as the horror film ''[[Blood Punch]]'', described the themes of the show as: friendship and love, magic, singing / music, and good vs. evil. She said the hardest part in writing an episode is the beginning and also in integrating the themes along with a story with a person that needs help. Her favourite scenes from the show were where the princesses are together doing ordinary teenage girl things as they had opportunities for comedy. She summarised the show as having something for everybody, very girly, but good action too.<ref name="paxson interview">{{Cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=efZf6fDXjqw |title=Interview with Writer Madellaine Paxson – Behind the Scenes – LoliRock |last=LoliRock |date=9 July 2015 |access-date=18 June 2016 |publisher=YouTube}}</ref> In the press release, Zodiak Kids describe the show as having a "cast of characters that are aspirational role models for a generation of children for whom justice has become a core value".<ref name="press 20150327"/> Jean-Louis Vandestoc chose a band concept for the series as it was different from his other shows which involved characters that went to school and then saved the world. The school part was replaced by the girls training or rehearsing for the concert.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/155290204503/from-where-will-come-the-idea-of-this-band |title=From where will come the idea of this band?? |last=Team LoliRock |date=2 January 2017 |access-date=16 January 2017 |work=Tumblr}}</ref> The developers later commented in their production blog [[FAQ]] that Iris was still attending school and that the episodes aren't all during summer vacation.<ref name="faq">{{cite web|url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/faq|title=F.A.Q.|author=Team LoliRock|work=Tumblr|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
According to posts on the production Tumblr, ''LoliRock'' is classified as somewhere between a script-driven and storyboard-driven show. They started with a full script and then recorded lines with scratch voices or final voices, as re-recording after storyboarding would be costlier. The storyboard is then worked on, and some of the storyboard artists and supervisor adding and changing things they felt were important such as with the kiss scene in the Shanila episode and the Iris becoming a dark princess. Storyboard stage also included fixes for continuity and plot holes.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/144656358703/hi-i-hope-you-had-a-good-day-d-i-was-wondering |title=Hi! I hope you had a good day :D I was wondering,... |last=Team LoliRock |date=20 May 2016 |access-date=15 June 2016 |work=Tumblr}}</ref>
===Music and voice-over=== The music score was composed and produced by Norbert "Yellowshark" Gilbert, with about 600 tracks over the course of the 52 26-minute episodes.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/142998972173/lolirock-score-show-reel-by-yellowshark-and | title=Team LoliRock – Lolirock Score Show Reel (by Yellowshark) And... | date=18 April 2016 | accessdate=15 June 2016 |work=Tumblr}}</ref> Five recurring songs (including the theme song) were recorded for each season. Due to limited resources in production, the team posted that Iris would be the only one singing on those songs, so they recorded Yasmin Shah in English and then developed the music videos. After realising that it would be unnatural for the other girls to not sing, they designed Iris to have a microphone while the others would just sing along. They considered recording singing for Talia and Auriana but were constrained by budget. Cassandre Berger provided the singing on the French dub. The voices were then mixed. As the dialogue was done later, the voice actors only sang on the incidental bits such as rehearsals.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/133350263328/lolirockers-fanquestions-songs-and-lyrics | title=Team LoliRock – LoliRockers FanQuestions : Songs and Lyrics | date=16 November 2015 | accessdate=15 June 2016 |work=Tumblr | author=Team LoliRock}}</ref>
The episodes were written and dubbed in English first and then adapted into French.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/153883769745/whoiam989-its-official-lolirock-is-written-and#notes|title=Team LoliRock – whoiam989: It's official. LoliRock is written and...|publisher=tumblr.com|accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref> For season 1, the English voices were recorded at Vida Spark Productions in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada,<ref name="english cast"/> while the French voices were recorded at Lylo studios in Paris, France.<ref name="french cast"/>
===Marketing and promotion=== Zodiak Media announced ''LoliRock'' in April 2013 at the [[MIPTV]] event in Cannes, France.<ref name="licensemag miptv"/> Early promotions included the idea of princesses with magical singing voices.<ref name="issuu catalog">{{cite web | url=https://issuu.com/zodiakmedia/docs/zodiak_kids_catalogue_2012/23 | title=Kids Catalogue | publisher=issuu.com | accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref> The demographic target audience is girls ages 6 to 12, and the group has partnered with France Televisions and Disney Channel France.<ref name="licensemag miptv">{{cite web | url=http://www.licensemag.com/license-global/miptv-kids-rule-cannes | title=MIPTV: Kids Rule in Cannes | work=License! Global | publisher=[[UBM plc|UBM]] | date=1 May 2013 | accessdate=18 June 2016 | last=Davis | first=Nicole}}</ref> Marathon Media CEO Vincent Chalvron-Demersay and general manager David Michel said that "LoliRock is a fresh, contemporary take on what it is to be a girl today, infused with music and magical adventures and the all-important notion of justice in today's teenage world. It's a perfect companion piece to ''[[Totally Spies!]]'', which has been so successful in this same space."<ref name="animation magazine 20130325">{{cite web | url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/tv/zodiak-to-launch-lolirock-at-miptv/ | title=Zodiak to Launch 'LoliRock' at MIPTV | work=Animation Magazine | date=25 March 2013 | accessdate=18 June 2016 | author=Milligan | first=Mercedes}}</ref> In comparing the promotion of the show to that of ''Totally Spies!'', Zodiak senior vice-president Patricia de Wilde said that Zodiak made sure the premise was made clear for the new show.<ref name="licensemag 20131001"/>
The five songs were publicised as music videos on YouTube.<ref name="licensemag 20131001"/> Plans were also made to create live-action ''LoliRock'' bands in various markets,<ref name="animation magazine 20130325"/> such as [[Super!|Super TV]]'s contest held online<ref>{{cite web | url=http://magiclolirock.blogspot.com/2016/04/super-tv-holds-lolirock-contest.html | title=Super TV! Holds a LoliRock Contest! | date=12 April 2016 | accessdate=18 June 2016 | author=MagicLoliRock |work=Blogspot}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.supertv.it/home/video-e-foto/Canta-con-le-LoliRock-Piu-Su.html | title=Canta con le LoliRock: Più Su! – Super! TV | work=supertv.it | accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref> and among major cities in Italy. A website was launched with videos, games, and message boards. Promotional toys were also offered at [[Quick (restaurant)|Quick restaurants]] as well as [[McDonald's]].<ref name="press 20150327">{{cite press release | url=https://www.zodiakkids.com/mcdonalds-signs-as-promotional-partner-for-lolirock/ | title=FRANCE: McDonalds signs up as promotional partner for Zodiak Kids’ Lolirock | date=27 March 2015 | author=Zodiak Media | accessdate=20 June 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.zodiakmedia.com/press_detail.php?id=747 | title=LoliRock Success in France & Italy | work=Zodiak Media | date=31 March 2016 | accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref><ref>References to Quick restaurant: * Bertrand Todesco announces Quick toys: {{cite web | url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/138538365158/bertrandtodesco-from-today-feb-2nd-of-2016 | title=Team LoliRock – bertrandtodesco: From today, Feb 2nd of 2016 | date=2 February 2016 | accessdate=18 June 2016 | last=Todesco | first=Bertrand |work=Tumblr}} * Dutch version of website showing LoliRock promotion: {{cite web | url=https://www.quick.be/nl/pagina/heldenkindermenus | title=Quick – De smaak en meer | work=[[Quick (restaurant)|Quick]] | accessdate=18 June 2016 | language=Dutch}} * French version of website showing LoliRock promotion: {{cite web | url=http://www.quick.be/fr/enfants | title=Quick – Le gout d'en faire plus | work=[[Quick (restaurant)|Quick]] | accessdate=19 June 2016 | language=French | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160214065602/http://www.quick.be/fr/enfants | archivedate=14 February 2016 | deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.licensemag.com/license-global/lolirock-arrives-happy-meals | title='LoliRock' Arrives in Happy Meals | work=License! Global | publisher=[[UBM plc|UBM]] | date=30 March 2015 | accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref> An app was developed for the music which Zodiak senior vice-president Patricia de Wilde said was a "sort of cross between K-Pop and Katy Perry."<ref name="licensemag 20131001"/>
== Broadcast == The show premiered on [[France 3]] on 18 October 2014.<ref name="premiere france 3">{{cite web|url=http://www.france5.fr/et-vous/userdata/a_augure_file/9/9955/France-3-Jeunesse-Toussaint-2014.pdf|title=France 5 : emissions, programme tv, infos et jeux|work=france5.fr|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="ep1 premiere">{{cite web|url=http://www.france3.fr/emission/lolirock/diffusion-du-18-10-2014-10h21 |title=LoliRock – L'audition – Samedi 18 Octobre 10h22 – Accueil |date=21 October 2014 |work=[[France 3]] |language=French |accessdate=20 June 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021194855/http://www.france3.fr/emission/lolirock/diffusion-du-18-10-2014-10h21 |archivedate=21 October 2014 |df= }}</ref> running for 13 episodes until March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france3.fr/emission/lolirock/diffusion-du-07-03-2015-07h26|title=LoliRock – Coup de foudre – Episode 7 – Samedi 7 Mars 07h27|work=[[France 3]] | language=French|deadurl=no |accessdate=20 June 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160620180108/http://www.france3.fr/emission/lolirock/diffusion-du-07-03-2015-07h26 | archivedate=20 June 2016 }}</ref><!-- NEED SOURCE in April 2015, it started airing in Spain on [[Disney Channel (Spain)|Disney Channel]], and started airing in [[Portugal]] on [[Canal Panda]], and in Italy on [[DeA Kids]]. The series seeks to extend throughout Europe and the songs have English versions. --> On 26 January 2016, [[Zodiak Kids]] published an article officially announcing that BatteryPOP had acquired AVOD (streaming) rights to LoliRock for one year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zodiakkids.com/batterypop-picks-up-avod-rights-to-lolirock-and-get-blake/|title=batteryPOP picks up AVOD rights to LoliRock and Get Blake!|work=Zodiak Kids}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.c21media.net/batterypop-unwraps-lolirock/|title=BatteryPop unwraps LoliRock|publisher=c21media.net|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref>
On 1 April, France Televisions announced the release of episodes on [[France 4]], and [[Disney Channel (France)|Disney France]]. Zodiak also reported that Italy would launch LoliRock on [[De Agostini]] Editore's [[Super!]] DTT channel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/tv/lolirock-attunes-to-france-and-italy/|title='LoliRock' Attunes to France and Italy|date=1 April 2016|publisher=animationmagazine.net|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> France 4 began broadcasting the 13 episodes on 4 April 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france4.fr/emission/54084b8970676526583bbe03/56ea37f6706765442ab60802 |title=LoliRock – L'audition – Saison 1 – Episode 1 – Lundi 4 Avril 13h35 |work=france4.fr |accessdate=20 June 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160620191029/http://www.france4.fr/emission/54084b8970676526583bbe03/56ea37f6706765442ab60802 |archivedate=20 June 2016 |df= }}</ref><!-- save to archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20160620191029/http://www.france4.fr/emission/54084b8970676526583bbe03/56ea37f6706765442ab60802 --> On 1 May, the first season of the series was released on [[Netflix]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/4/29/11536358/netflix-amazon-prime-hbo-now-new-movies-tv-shows-may-2016|title=Everything coming to Netflix, Amazon Prime, and HBO Now in May|work=[[The Verge]]|last=Bishop|first=Bryan|date=29 April 2016|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/143676391688/todays-the-day | title=Team LoliRock – Today's the day. :) | date=1 May 2016 | accessdate=15 June 2016 |work=Tumblr | author=Team LoliRock }}</ref> in the United States, Canada, United Kingdom and Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://unogs.com/video/?v=80101826|title=Netflix Global Search on uNoGS|website=unogs.com|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>
The ''LoliRock'' producers pre-released the four episodes of season 2 on YouTube on December 2016.<ref name="season 2 preview">{{cite web|url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/154596804053/omg-season-2-the-first-episode-it-was-so|title=Omg season 2, the first episode, it was so...|publisher=tumblr.com|accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref> Netflix released the English dub of the season 2 episodes on 5 January 2017.<ref name="season 2 jan">{{cite web|url=http://teamlolirock.tumblr.com/post/155486278533/so-season-2-on-netflix|title=So, Season 2 on Netflix...|publisher=tumblr.com|accessdate=14 February 2017}}</ref><!-- 5 January confirmed by actual visit to Netflix website, 6 January is provided here as acknowledgement by LoliRock tumblr production team --> It was broadcast on France 4 in February with two episodes per weekday.<!-- see episodes list -->
===Episodes=== {{Main article|List of LoliRock episodes}} {{:List of LoliRock episodes}}
==Reception== Ella Anders of BSC Kids wrote that ''LoliRock'' "plays it clear as a magical girl series and even nods other iconic shows in the genera" such as ''[[Pretty Cure]]'' and ''[[Sailor Moon]]'', but that it is "grand in its own right and should be held up as a great magical girl series". She liked the diverse cast, plot, humor and background story, the last of which she had not seen since ''[[My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic]]'', and that it was a type of show she would have loved growing up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsckids.com/2016/04/lolirock-arrives-long-last-us/|title=Lolirock Arrives at Long Last to US|date=27 April 2016|publisher=bsckids.com|accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref>
Heather Newman of ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine described the series as "A French animated series about an impossibly thin, stylish, magical girl who sings."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/hnewman/2016/04/29/new-on-netflix-sherlock-doc-grace-and-frankie-sixteen-candles/|title=New on Netflix: 'Sherlock' Doc, 'Grace And Frankie,' 'Sixteen Candles'|first=Heather|last=Newman|work=[[Forbes]]|date=29 April 2016|accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref>
When asked whether ''LoliRock'' would have a cross-over episode with French superhero show ''[[Miraculous: Tales of Ladybug & Cat Noir]]'' from [[Zagtoon]], Thomas Astruc, who was the creator and director on ''Miraculous'' and a storyboarder on ''LoliRock'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/thomas-astruc-48b3a311|title=Thomas Astruc|publisher=linkedin.com|accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref> said it was unlikely given they are from two different production companies, but that the animation community is small and that both companies share the same love of animation. He has posted about the two being cousin shows.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsckids.com/2015/12/countdown-to-miraculous-is-on/|title=Countdown to Miraculous Tales of Ladybug & Cat Noir Is On|date=5 December 2015|publisher=bsckids.com|accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)-->
== Other media == A ''LoliRock'' video game, available on iOS and Android, was released by Bulkypix in 2014. The game lets players sing to the songs featured on the show, record performances, and customise a sound studio and pick the girls' outfits.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.droidgamers.com/index.php/game-news/android-game-news/8054-lolirock-arrives-onto-android-so-you-can-sing-along-to-their-songs|title=LoliRock arrives onto Android so you can sing along to their songs|author=AndrewH|publisher=droidgamers.com}}</ref>
Zodiak has also worked a deal with publishing company Hachette Jeunesse to create novels, activity books, stationery, and e-books.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.zodiakmedia.com/press_detail.php?id=551|title=Zodiak Kids and Hachette Jeunesse sign LOLIROCK Publishing deal | date=15 October 2013 | work=Zodiak Media | accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref>

{{lead too short|date=October 2015}} [[File:Max Stern in Germany, c. 1925.jpg|thumbnail|Max Stern in Germany, c. 1925]] '''Max Stern''' (1904-1987) was a [[Germans|German]]-[[Canadians|Canadian]] arts benefactor, art historian, and owner of [[Montreal]]'s landmark Dominion Gallery (in French, ''Galerie Dominion'').
== Life before WWII == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Stern Gallery.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Dr. Max Stern]] --> Max Stern was born in [[Mönchen-Gladbach]], [[Germany]], in April 1904. His father, Julius Stern, was a German-born Jew who worked in the textile industry, and later went into business as an art dealer. Before Max was born, his father was a prestigious art collector, and by [[World War I]], had become one of the most prominent gallery owners in [[Düsseldorf]].<ref name=Pageot>{{cite book|last=Pageot|first=Edith-Anne|title=Max Stern : Montreal Dealer and Patron|year=2004|publisher=Montreal Museum of Fine Arts|location=Montreal|page=15}}</ref> For this reason, Max led a privileged childhood, immersed in Germanic culture. He had his family's full support in pursuing his doctoral studies in art history. He studied in [[Cologne]], [[Berlin]], [[Vienna]] and [[Paris]], and earned his doctorate from the [[University of Bonn]] in 1928.<ref name=Dombowsky>{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|page=3}}</ref> He then decided to become the Stern Gallery manager. His father died in 1934 and Max became the new gallery owner.<ref name=Pageot />
==During the war== Stern's ambitions grew once he became gallery owner. He hoped to one day operate galleries in [[Düsseldorf]], [[London]] and [[New York City]]. Eventually with the help of his sister and the Dutch art historian Cornelius van de Wetering, Stern managed to open a gallery in [[London]]. The official opening occurred in 1935.<ref name="Dombowsky 5">{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|page=5}}</ref>
Unfortunately, Stern's future plans were disrupted with the rise of [[Nazism]] in Germany. He received notification from the Reich Chamber of Fine Arts that he had lost his [[professional accreditation]], and was given four weeks to either sell or dissolve all holdings within the Galerie Stern.<ref name="MacKenzie 13">{{cite book|last=MacKenzie|first=Catherine Mary|title=Auktion 392 : Reclaiming the Galerie Stern, Dèusseldorf|year=2006|publisher=Concordia University|location=Montreal|page=13}}</ref> He [[appealed]] the [[mandate (criminal law)|mandate]], while trying to find a suitable [[Aryan]] citizen to assume ownership. While the gallery was temporarily "Aryan", Stern planned to open another outside Germany and wait out the [[Third Reich]].<ref name="MacKenzie 13" /> To achieve these means, he chose [[Netherlands|Dutch]] art historian Nathan Katz.
Unfortunately, the Nazi Chamber of Fine Arts decided that the gallery was too important to fall into the hands of a foreigner, and would consider no future deals. In September 1937, Stern was given 17 days to close his business.<ref name="MacKenzie 13" /> The reason for this forced closure was that all [[Jewish]] citizens had been forbidden from selling art. In November, Stern was forced to [[auction]] off a large segment of the Stern Gallery by order of the [[Nazi government]]. These artworks were sold in one of Germany's oldest auction houses, Kunsthaus Lempertz. They went on the block by their lot number, Auktion 392.<ref name=Website>{{cite web|last=Leo Baeck Institute|title="Auktion 392" – Reclaiming the Galerie Stern|url=http://www.lbi.org/2007/02/auktion-392-reclaiming-the-galerie-stern/|publisher=Federal Foreign Office|accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref> Not all pieces were sold, and Stern placed those that remained in storage with shipping agent Josef Roggendorf. Roggendorf held the artwork close to the Düsseldorf gallery until it was all confiscated by the National Socialist government.<ref name=Dombowsky />
Stern then spent several years trying to track down the 28 confiscated paintings. He created an advertisement in the German art magazine ''Die Weltkunst'', offering a reward for any information pertaining to the paintings' locations.<ref name=Dombowsky /> Recovering the paintings proved to be extremely difficult. ''Musical Party'' by [[Dirck Hals]] and ''Landscape with Figures'' by [[Salomon van Ruysdael]] were eventually recovered with help from the [[Canadian government]] after the war had ended. ''Last Judgment'' by [[Hieronymus Bosch]] was returned in 1954. Other works were never found.<ref name=Dombowsky />
==Post-war== Stern fled Germany in December, 1937, reportedly carrying nothing but a small suitcase. He decided to join his sister at the gallery in London. Their plans to develop further were interrupted a few years later once the war began. Stern was interred as an enemy alien in a [[refugee camp]] on the [[Isle of Man]] for two years.<ref name=Dombowsky /> The British government then allowed him to [[immigrate]] to [[Canada]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Rossouw|first=Henk|title=In Pursuit of an Art Dealer's Dream|year=2006|publisher=The Chronicle of Higher Education}}</ref> Stern sailed on the Polish liner ''Sobiski'',<ref name=Pageot /> but was unable to get his money and belongings out of [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. He then spent two years in [[internment camps]] in [[New Brunswick]] and [[Quebec]].<ref name=Dombowsky /> He was given [[refugee status]] upon his arrival. He took steps to be exempted from this status, and made contact with the man who ran the Canadian Refugee Organization, William Birks, who immediately vouched for Stern.
Because of Stern's academic background and art dealing experience, he was named director of the Dominion Gallery of Fine Art. In January 1947, Stern and his wife became the sole proprietors of Gallery Dominion. He met his wife at the Canadian Refugee organization. She was a Swedish woman named Iris Westerberg.<ref>{{cite book|last=Pageot|first=Edith-Anne|title=Max Stern : Montreal Dealer and Patron|year=2004|publisher=Montreal Museum of Fine Arts|location=Montreal|page=16}}</ref> Together, they made the gallery a focal point for the distribution of living art by Canadian artists. Both were known for promoting young and unknown Canadian art talents.
1944 was an especially important year for Stern's promotion of [[Canadian art]]. During this year, he held separate exhibitions featuring art by four members of the [[Group of Seven (artists)|Group of Seven]] and [[Emily Carr]].<ref name="Dom 5-6">{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|pages=5–6}}</ref>
Stern made many important contributions towards Canadian art culture. In the 1940s he provided a means for young Canadian artists to paint on a full-time basis by establishing a contract system. In this system, monthly payments are made to the artist in exchange for an agreed number of works. This method has since been used successfully in [[France]], [[England]] and the [[United States]].<ref name="Dom 5-6" />
In 1950, Stern moved the Dominion Gallery to a three-story building in a different area of Montreal. This new building allowed for 14 exhibition rooms and an apartment on the upper level where Stern and his wife would live.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|page=6}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:'Ships in Distress on a Stormy Sea' by Jan Porcellis.jpg|thumb|''Ships in a Stormy Sea'', painting by [[Jan Porcellis]] recovered in 2016 and now in the [[Frans Hals Museum]]]] Max Stern is remembered as an icon within the art society worldwide. Upon leaving [[Europe]], Stern raised the level of art appreciation in Canada. He began donating to Canadian institutions in the mid-1950s, and gave generously to several [[museums]] across Canada. He was especially generous to [[Montreal]] institutions, donating over 166 works.<ref name="Dom 7">{{cite book|last=Dombowsky|first=Philip|title=Dr. Max Stern and the Dominion Gallery a Selection from the Archives|year=2003|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|location=Ottawa|page=7}}</ref>
True to his occupation until the very end, Stern died on a business trip in [[Paris]]. For his contributions he received countless acknowledgements and awards, including an [[honorary doctorate]] from [[Concordia University]] in 1985. The gallery continued to operate for more than a decade after Stern's death, closing in December 2000.<ref name="Dom 7" />
The [[Max Stern Art Restitution Project]] was jointly created by the [[Hebrew University in Jerusalem]], [[McGill University]], [[Concordia University]] and the Holocaust Claims Processing Office in New York. The project's initiative has been to locate and recover works from the original Stern collection that were lost during the 1930s. The collection held an estimated 400 pieces in total.<ref name="Dr. Max Stern and his Gallery and Art Collection from 1933-1945 and after World War II">{{cite web|last=Korte|first=Willi|title=Dr. Max Stern and his Gallery and Art Collection from 1933-1945 and after World War II|url=https://www.concordia.ca/arts/max-stern/context.html|publisher=Concordia University|accessdate=22 November 2013}}</ref> Sadly, less than twenty of these paintings have been recovered to date. A long and arduous project, efforts are still being made to recover all Stern pieces lost under the Nazi regime.
In 2017 a scheduled exhibition in Dusseldorf about Stern and the Restitution Project was abruptly cancelled due to local opposition, leading to intense controversy.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/art-and-architecture/dusseldorfs-cancellation-of-show-about-jewish-art-dealer-max-stern-sparksoutrage/article37080276/ |title=Restoration drama |last=Angel |first=Sara |date=24 November 2017 |website= |publisher=The Globe and Mail |access-date=13 December 2017 |quote=Dusseldorf's cancellation of show about Jewish art dealer Max Stern sparks outrage}}</ref>
==Selected art pieces donated by Dr. and Mrs. Stern==
* Painting: ''Pensive girl''. Artist: [[Prudence Heward]]. Donated to: [[The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts]]. * Painting: ''The Flayed Woman''. Artist: [[Paul-Emile Borduas]]. Donated to: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. * Painting: ''Little Girl in Blue''. Artist: [[Jori Smith]]. Donated to: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. * Painting: ''Woman on a Sofa''. Artist: [[Kees Van Dongen]]. Donated to: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. * Painting: ''Community House (Ucluelet)''. Artist: [[Emily Carr]]. Donated to: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts.
== Artists Stern represented == * [[Jean Arp]] * [[Paul-Émile Borduas]] * [[Emily Carr]] * Stanley Cosgrove * [[Jacques de Tonnancour]] * Louise Gadbois * Francois Gall * [[Eric Goldberg (artist)|Eric Goldberg]] * [[E. J. Hughes]] * [[Wassily Kandinsky]] * J D Lawley * [[Henry Moore]] * [[Gordon Pfeiffer|Gordon Edward Pfeiffer]] * [[Jeanne Rhéaume]] * [[Goodridge Roberts]] * [[Auguste Rodin]] * Marian Scott * [[Paul Soulikias]]<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vzM2s6FJO-4 "Steppin' Out" (1982). CBC television Montreal Channel 6. 25 November.]</ref> * [[Gentile Tondino]] * [[Tristan Tondino]]
